en: Disclaimer 1: This story and the names, places, and countries mentioned in it are completely fictitious. Any resemblance to anything, any person living or dead, or any event in real life is just a co-incidence.

Disclaimer 2: The following story is narrated by a character, whose views and opinions the author or anyone else in the team does not agree with. The idea with said narration is to present a story of complicated characters, whose viewpoints and POV may not be good or reliable. The purpose of this tale is not to offend any person on their sexuality, race, gender, appearance, or nationality. The sole purpose is to present a mysterious tale that may have a main character who is complicated in his views and behavior, and the same thing is with the characters around him. Still, in case of any discomfort, you are free to turn the game off, and move onto something lighter. Also, one last thing, take this or any other jam submission at your own reading pace, and try not to rush them. All the entries have something important to say or tell, and the more you soak each word in with patience, the better the experience. With these out of the way, please enjoy this short tale that we hastily put together for 2023's Nanoreno Jam. Hopefully in time to not be disqualified.

Disclaimer 3: In case you are Let's Player/Streamer somehow finding this very obscure piece of game and then having to find themselves narrate to your audience, speaking all of the words bit-by-bit in your lovely voice. Well, then all I can say is....stay hydrated.
[center]ACT ONE: A STRESSFUL DAY[/center]
Oh, hello!
Good to see you here.
Please stay for a while in our great nation of [i]Yhafa[/i].
I can ensure you that it is a beautiful country,
filled with rich country music that pledges our loyalty towards the motherland,
with grasses that sway with the ever colder winds of our mountains
and working people with ever widening smiles on their faces,
living in a nation that stands at the height of prosperity in major areas of human development ...
like filmmaking, agriculture exports, lithium mines, ethnic unification, weapons research & development, and worshiping by economic leaders from other countries ...
and soon enough I ensure you that we will be a global superpower....
Well, I might be getting ahead of myself right now,
sorry for that.
You are new to my country,
and so you might take some time to adapt.
Anyway,
it is nice to meet you,
my name is....
Ronan Isidro.
I am the Head Clerk and Head Communication manager of the second division of the unit, Terra-3.
Terra-3 is very important for the [i]Yhafa[/i] army, as we are the backbone of all communications between many-a-sectors of the military.
Therefore, I am responsible for many high rank communications that are carried out between the higher ups at the military of [i]Yhafa[/i] and the brave soldiers working on the ground.
I am a passionate patriot, as everyone should be.
In fact, my first ever memory was not that of seeing the smiling face of my mother,

who was weak enough to die giving birth to me, leaving me to spend the rest of my childhood with my father's second wife until I was eight, and then spent the rest of my teenage years in the military boarding school.
By the time that I graduated and started becoming a part of the military itself, my father had already married two more times.
The latest being with a woman that was two years younger than me.
How's my father now?
Well, for all I know, he still probably lives on the high mountains in that mansion of his,
accompanied by his riches and that young wife of his.
We haven't been in contact for ten years at this point and despite my father's plea-filled letters to my wife;
I would prefer it to stay that way.
Sorry about that, you know how it can be sometimes with families and old stuff.
My father was never loyal, but just so you know, I have pledged to myself, my wife, and my country that I wish to stay loyal and faithful to my one beloved.
After all, any poster in [i]Yhafa[/i] can tell you that a healthy family is where the father and mother stick together,
and they produce one son for the nation's defenses,
and one daughter for the nation's populace,
and I believe in that message whole-heartedly,
for even if you are not from [i]Yhafa[/i],
won't you agree that it is the
perfect family combination!
Anyway, about my first memory.

My first ever memory was from when I briefly visited my now deceased grandfather's house in the Seoking village, in the state of Tarimata, which then lay on the borders of the former nation of [i]Conferri[/i].
My grandfather used to say that the village served as a border itself, and at some point, while there were no fences, tombstones, or soldiers to divide the area,
there were only two wide flags that flowed around with the strong winds that blew them.
My first memory, you see, is of that blue flag of [i]Conferri[/i] falling to the ground,
because in the war of unification,
the only flag that remained standing was of my nation.
I still remember the yellow sky above, and the sun shining so brightly.
I still remember the black smokes of victory,
as the once lost nation of [i]Conferri[/i] found its way back to its motherland and unified in its care.
Buildings and houses that were made of straws and poor cements burned in the fire of reinvention.

Three years later, like a phoenix, those places rose to prominence, as now right there stands a museum of our history, in its shiny new marble walls, whose each square inch glitter against both the strong rays of our father sun, and the gentle white blanket of mother moon.
So yeah,
my first memory is of the flag of an already declining nation falling,
and my flag standing still proudly. Our nation was united once again, as it were before the reign of Hindaravs.
Even though my grandfather is long dead,
I still visit my village from time to time for two activities.
To pay respects to the grave of my now departed Grandpa, Souka Isidro,
and to salute the flag that has made me the bold man that I am today.
It has been twenty years since the unification, and while the red sun...may fall against the evening melodies,
the red flag stands against the rough and tear of unpredictable weather and flows boldly.
My apologies, I might have gone on a tangent again.
You see, I love my country, as any person instilled with great values would.
But still, it looks like my country will never know of my dedication, and it isn't my motherland's fault. For you see, I am about to tell you a tale.
A tale that will explain how I ended in this deep,
dark,
and empty space,
whose corners and skies are impossible to find.
A tale of the injustice that was done to me, my wife, and my son, by the enemies of the motherland.
When it all ends,
I am pretty sure that you ...
the new or already existing loyal child of mother [i]Yhafa[/i] (and do not worry, for mother [i]Yhafa[/i]'s arms are open to all, so feel free to join) ...
would agree, that, whatever happened to me and the ones I loved, is a great injustice.
I cannot tell the nature of this injustice...
...or what caused it, but you know it to be true.
A family that is as dedicated to god as it is dedicated to the country, clearly deserved better.
However, what can anyone do when tragedy strikes?
For when disturbed forces
(that is, the people who refuse any help to control the chaos inside them, which allows discipline to abandon their minds)
let their lack of direction lead to chaos and traitorous activities,
then it is the innocent and well-bled people like us who bite the bullet.
Sorry, I let myself rant again.
So foolish of me.
I apologize for my disturbing and incoherent ramblings.
I did not wish to waste your time like this, but....
what can we do...
emotions aren't a straight stream of a river you know...
And even if you are some hidden spy of those who still believe that [i]Conferri[/i] would ever be a thing again,
you will agree that it is a just simile to say that emotions are like rain, when they are released, they fall everywhere and anywhere.
He. He. He. He. He.
He. He. He. He. He. He.
He. He. He. He. He. He.
Sorry,
it is just so funny.
If our great warriors were nearby,
they would laugh at me for my signs of weakness.....
well, I guess that's why it happened to me...
I-It happened to me...
[color=red]Because I was weak.[/color]
As far as I can remember,
it was probably a cloudy day.
I can't say that with full confidence, because the office that was provided to me was severely malnourished when it came to lighting.
It was not as if light never seeped inside, but the amount was so low that you couldn't accurately tell what was actually happening with the sky.
You could very well see yellow rays of light seeping in, only to find the weather outside to be all grey, and only some small miraculous clouds drift above,
letting a few escaping rays of light into the office.
And for the past three days I was basically locked inside,
having eaten or drunk very little and being in a constant state of panic from start to end.\n\n
The thing was that for the past four days,
near the [i]Ufana[/i] prefecture in Division 6 outpost,
student rallies suddenly erupted.
At first, it was just a few pro-Conferri students forming a union to demonstrate and shout for their supposed-freedom.

From what I understand, the demonstration area was secured by fraud, as the students pretended to ask the area permission for a play that they had prepared in honor of our leader, however, when blue banners, microphones, and chants of 'Free us! Free us!' started to surround the area, the authorities realized that something was wrong.
'Sorry, am I hearing this correctly?
Did you ask for a transfer of 19 soldiers to [i]Ufana[/i] prefecture or 90?'
My hands gripped the receiver of the telephone tightly.
Sweat was trickling down my body, as the last drop of water that I had not so long ago evaporated from my throat.
I was taking dry gulps, for I had no more saliva to produce inside my body.
The angry voice on the other side replied.
'How did it come to 90?! I...COFF...COFF...COFFF...'
Three small coughs escaped my mouth.
They were dry.
I could almost feel the skin inside my throat itching with god knows how many smaller red swollen spots growing from a lack of hydration.\n\n
'Rikki! You said you would have it handled by yesterday.
It has been 24 hours since yesterday!
It's not yesterday anymore, it is today now! Do you have any idea the scolding I am going to get from the general!'
'Look,' Rikki's voice was frustrated on the other side, 'If you weren't a personal friend and your wife wasn't a midwife to mine, I would've ordered your brains bashed with a brick right now.
You understand that!
I am already maxed out on handing shit here!
The last thing I wish to hear is your pathetic screaming!
DO YOU UNDERSTAND THAT!'
'I-I....coff...' a small, weak cough escaped from a man who was reminded of both his position and privilege.
Still, humbleness never hydrated anyone's throat or took away anyone's nausea.
My voice was still going to sound rough and scream all the same.
I stressed hard on my throat again, trying my best at clearing it somehow, so my voice could be more prim and proper.
However, all that escaped from me was more coughing.\n\n
'Ronan! You there...' Rikki's voice reverberated from the telephone.
I was so stressed out that every time Rikki said anything, the voice came inside my ears like nails on a chalkboard.
My body at that time had a lot of demands that circumstances weren't allowing to be full-filled.
My mind wished for peace.
My throat wished for water.
But most of all, my joints wished for a more comfortable place to sit in than the steel chair that was provided to me.

I had even scratched my hands once or twice before because of how rusty it was. I had demanded changes before, like a month before, but ordering a comfortable chair for work, even for the Head Clerk and Manager of the Communication Department of an important division, was a difficult task.

To be honest, the entire division was underfunded for years at this point, as most of the funds of reconstruction...and weaponry was sent to outposts at the border with our neighbor, Sutwandra, who held many exiles from the [i]Conferri[/i] unification.
We were a communication and clerical HQ anyway, so it shouldn't have been much of a problem.
Since most of our military spending obviously went to getting and maintaining communication devices like phones and radio signals, and clerical equipments like typewriter, papers, and folders.
So I shouldn't be complaining much,
but at a time of stress like that, you could not help but wish for at least something better to sit on.
'RONAN!'
Rikki's scream woke me from my fragile state.
I gripped the receiver harder, feeling the sweat that dropped from my forehead to the upper-cap of the receiver and slowly trickled down from its handle, to rejoin my body at my hand again.
'RONAN! Reply goddamn it!'
Rikki's scream turned into a full blown command.
When nauseous, you could try your best to avoid a scream, but it is always advisable to those who wished to see another day to never ever disobey a command from your superior.
Even if you are dead, make sure you follow whatever is asked from you.
Yes, you must be laughing at that last sentence right now.
I can only wish I could laugh with you.
'How can a person obey commands when they are already dead?'
Well my grandfather used to say it all the time that fear, you see, is something that is carried in the soul, not in the body.
And if there was one thing that the superiors of the [i]Yhafa[/i]in army were good at instilling, it was the fear of their commands.
In fact, at the risk of taking you away from the main tale for a while, here is a joke that is very common in [i]Yhafa[/i]...s army camps:

[i]Once a general asked one of the soldiers to buy some vegetables from the market. On the way back, his jeep was attacked by terrorists, and nothing but the hand of the soldier survived. Two days later, in the town, talks of a mysterious hand hopping around started to make rounds.[/i]

[i]An army guard told the newspaper, 'I saw a hand, yes, just a hand, steal my underwear', / a captured terrorist told the newspaper, 'I saw a hand, yes, just a hand, punch me, because of which I was captured',[/i]

[i]and a vegetable seller told the newspaper, 'I saw a hand, yes, just a hand, bring me a shopping bag, inside of which was a list of vegetables and a note of 2,000 and 250 tombs, combining together a price of 2,250 tombs from which the hand bought from me a pair of cauliflowers, two bottle gourds, some herbs, and half-a-kilogram of tomatoes.'[/i]\n\n
[i]As the general was reading the tale of this mysterious hand in the newspaper, there was a knock on his door.[/i]
[i]He opened the door and found a hand,[/i]
[i]yes, just a hand,[/i]
[i]dragging along a shopping bag full of vegetables.[/i]
[i]The general picked up the bag, and the hand looked up in anticipation, wishing for the general's permission to finally die.[/i]\n\n

[i]But instead the general said, 'Oh, today we have some important guests coming! Can you bring me some fresh wine from the brewery? And while you are at it, please take my dog out for a walk as well.'[/i]
He. He.
Wasn't that funny?
I remember having such a laugh at that one when we were in the training camps.
Those were simpler times, it was a time when Rikki and I were in the same position, and I was the one who always protected his mixed race self from being bullied by other cadets.
About Rikki?
Mixed race you ask?
Well, the story is simple.
Even after 110 years of independence from the [i]Hindarav[/i] empire and 100 years of [i]Conferri[/i] separation,
Yhafa and [i]Conferri[/i] were both still in a state of poverty.
Rikki's mother was an activist from some white country, I don't remember its name, but it was either Terro or Tearao.
The pronunciation for both countries is kind of the same to be honest.
Well, long story short, she moved to [i]Yhafa[/i] some ten years before Rikki...s birth, fell in love with Rikki's father, married and gave birth to Rikki

(whose name, if i may clarify, is somewhat written in similar veins to the traditional [i]Yhafa[/i] name ...Riki... with an extra k, and pronounced like the english name ...Ricky..., in order to honor both the parents lineage)
and then later was stabbed in the chest by her own husband, who grew jealous every time she even laid eyes on another man.
So,
back in training years, it was me protecting Rikki,
but over the years, he managed to garner a higher position in the army.
We still loved each other like brothers, but in moments like these he sometimes had a tendency to lose his temper.\n\n
Again,
he is not a bad person, I can assure you.
You are just seeing him at his worst self,
a self that is so stressed that it doesn't know what it may say.
'Y-yes, sir,' the voice escaped me.
The throat was still rough and dry, so I seriously don't know if Rikki received it as gently as I wished for it to,
or if he heard my calm reply as yet another scream of anger and frustration on him.
'Look, just forward the message to the General. Things are really out of control here.'
His voice seemed calm at this point, maybe he received my earlier reply as I wished for him to receive, or maybe, he had realized that there were bigger concerns at hand.
Either way, I was in a safe position for now.
'Well, Rikki...'

I had almost forgotten my place again, thank god that I had some sane consciousness left to add, '...sir. I would still...I-I mean....COFF...COFF....the general would still need an explanation about why the situation that was promised to be resolved by yesterday is still persisting today.
And why is there a sudden demand of over 90 soldiers...'\n\n
Before I could continue further,
Rikki's panicked voice said, '60!
Tell him 60, not 90.
I think I might be overshooting his and your patience with 90,
60 must be enough! Yes,
yes,
tell him 60!'
'Well,' Despite the explanation, I was trying to make the best sense of the sudden change in numbers, 'The general would still demand an explanation.'\n\n
'Well, tell the general that someone provided the student groups with weapons themselves, and I ain't just talking about guns and pistols, they got hand-grenades as well.
Worst of all, it is not just the students now, but almost the entire prefecture that is being a pain for us.
They have barricaded their houses to the military, and most people are refusing to surrender.
We are somehow outnumbered and outgunned.
We have lost the only tank we had on this outpost. Nobody even knows when it got blown up...it just fucking did.
They are playing that dead old [i]Conferri[/i] national anthem again and again on the loudspeakers as well.
That fucking song is like someone scratching thermocol sheet I tell you!'
I stressed my ears a little, and was able to make out some of the lyrics of the song.

Mainly the â€˜[i]for winds be the god, angels be the tree, when you stretch your eyes around, you will see the land of free,[/i]' part of the song that usually was just a medium pitched part of the song, was recorded in the highest of pitch, especially the word, 'free'.
It was basically not even high pitched, but a scream.
'It's alright Rikki sir, it's alright,' I tried being reassuring the entire time, wishing not to trouble him any further, 'I will forward the message to the general.'

'Good, try to make it quick please. I do not know how longer we can hold. They have already replaced some of the [i]Yhafa[/i] flags with the [i]Conferri[/i] flags. The gall of these people I tell you.'
I...crashed down on the chair muttering, 'No, please...please', to myself.
Sweat was still trickling down my entire body, and I could only wish for it to stop.
My body was aching all over the place, if my mind even had a second's rest to think anything, it would've wished for me to die.
Just imagining those flags going down sent shivers to my body.
I staggered out of my chair, picked up the telephone, and dialed the number of my junior clerk.
Before I could even hear a single ring on my side, the junior clerk picked it up.\n\n
'What can I do for you sir?'\n\n
I had called him so many times in the span of three days that at this point all formalities or praising the nation was off the table.
All information needed to be conveyed swiftly.
'I would be calling the general in a few minutes.
Tell all the troops neighboring the [i]Ufana[/i] prefecture, or the Segami city itself to await an order of troop deployment.'
My voice was getting raspy at this point, I sounded forty years older than I actually was, 'And tell them to do it quick.
This situation in [i]Ufana[/i] is turning into a situation Dragon.
I am pretty sure the foreign press had gotten their hands on this by now, and would be airing this debacle all over the world.
Trying to suppress the information flow is useless, focus on the counter-measures and we will focus on the foreign and domestic media circulation later on.
You understand that!'
'Yes, sir,'
It was then I noticed that the voice on the other side was raspy as well.
In fact, I am pretty sure the entire office by now was filled with dry throats.\n\n
'And soldier...'
I replied with the calmest voice I can muster, 'Take a two minute water break for everyone. And tell Seiko to bring a glass of water to my office as well.'
'Sir,' the junior said on the other end,
'Can it be three, we have had two people who have already fainted, and it has only been three hours since Isamu was hospitalized after his collapse.'\n\n
'Huh,'
a long sigh escaped me, 'I will make it three minutes, but that is all the exception I can allow. The situation is really off the rails here.
And about Isamu...'
I knew I was on the telephone, but I could clearly tell that he was pressing his ear very close to the receiver, holding his breath intently.
Isamu was a dear friend of his, just like how I was with Rikki.
He was almost sixty years old at that point, and had served the motherland 42 years straight without ever asking for any promotion.
Even I had a certain respect for the old fellow.
'You can rest assured that no one will know that he collapsed.
I will write in the papers that I sent him out on an important errand, or maybe even as a protection for Seiko when she needed to travel to the nearby outpost to issue supply demands.
Just make sure he recovers fast, I cannot keep up the lie forever.'
As soon as I finished talking, his grateful voice replied,
'Thank you! Thank you sir!'
'Now, please get on moving.
The break is only three minutes, and I desperately wish to have some water myself.'
My eyes closed for a minute or two, wishing for a rest from looking at things.
For the past three days I had only managed to sleep around 1 hour minimum, and 3 hours max.
My eyes were as red as they came, and if someone didn't know better, they would think I watched television all day with my face just inches away from the screen.

I don't know when, but Seiko might have come in and quietly put the glass of water on my table without disturbing my half-asleep self (which she knew was in an immense state of stress) and exited the office.
When I opened my eyes, I drank three quick gulps of water, and letting out a long sigh from my mouth I returned to work again.
I had one hand holding the receiver, and another with my palm spread over my heart.
I don't know which one was left and which one was right and at this point, I didn't even know what was half of my body doing half the time.
It was basically running on auto-pilot.\n\n
[i]Tring. Tring.[/i]
\n\nThe line on the other side kept ringing, and my ears remained fixated.
Even though I knew what the general was probably going to say, I wanted him to just pick it up, shout at me, give me orders, and get over it.
The longer the line on the other side rang, the longer my heart raced.
At this point I felt like it was going to stop at any moment.
'Love to [i]Yhafa[/i]!'

A female voice chanted on the other side, it was a little rough and cranky, if one of my wife's friend's voices didn't sound exactly similar, I would've thought that someone put a 14-year-old boy on the other side.
Still, listening to a womanly voice like hers, made me want to go home to my wife again.
Kaede was probably in the shrine then, climbing the 19,999 stairs barefooted.

I am pretty sure that earlier she just planned to pray for a healthy birth of our son that was 8 months old in her belly at this point, but considering the situation now, praying for my safety was definitely added to her list of prayers.\n\n
'This is General Himekawa's office speaking, how can I help?'

The receptionist's voice was huffing and puffing all over the place. With each word that she said, there were exhaustive breaths accompanying them. She and her lungs both just wanted to get over with this.\n\n
If it was any other day, I would've judged her harshly.
However, as the situation stood around, I could do nothing but empathize with her.

'Love to [i]Yhafa[/i] to you as well! This is Officer Isidro speaking, requesting immediate word with the General. Know that there can't be much delay in communication, the situation is kind of important and needs a word with immediacy.'
I don't know how I managed to get that entire sentence out of the way without even coughing once, but it felt like my throat was finally going easy on me.\n\n
'COFF...COFF...ack...' Well, I celebrated too soon.\n\n

'Sir are you alright?' The receptionist's voice spoke out in concern. I could've replied saying, 'the same thing goes for you!' because her voice sounded at the edge of breaking, but for now, I decided to avoid any unnecessary comments.\n\n
'Just establish communication with the General.
That's an order.'
She didn't reply much after that, and just four and a half minutes later, the general was on the line.\n\n
'Isidro...'
From the general's voice I knew he was mad.
How could he not?
The thing was supposed to be suppressed and wrapped up by yesterday, but now things were getting out of hand.
I wouldn't blame him for being mad, I would be mad too if I was in his place.\n\n
'General...'
The air around me was getting tighter and tighter.
If I could, I would've punched a hole on the wall just so I could smell some air coming in.\n\n
'What's the news from the outpost at [i]Ufana?[/i]'\n\n

'Sir, the outpost in [i]Ufana[/i] has requested up to 60 ground soldiers or 60 counter-terrorism enforcement on nearby districts and outposts. Apparently, students and rebels related to the free [i]Conferri[/i] movement have more ammunition and weapon types. There are also loud source propagandas in relation to free [i]Conferri[/i] movement recorded and broadcasted through loudspeakers all over the area, whose initial sources are yet to be determined. We are trying not to shoot out the loudspeakers until the source is located.'
I almost expected the general to scream at this point, my heart was even ready for it.
However, I heard three taps of finger on the table, and then, 'Blow up the buildings.'
'I-I am sorry sir. But the repairs of the infrastructure cost would...'\n\n
'With all due respect officer, I DON'T FUCKING CARE!

This incident has already gone international, and similar protests are erupting in [i]Youkandero[/i] and [i]Eragonate[/i] as well. This situation has gone out of hand by giving these terrorists much more attention than they needed.
I have already gotten four calls from our great leader himself, and he is furious. At one point he even said that my head could be on the chopping block.
Well, officer, I think you understand that if my fucking head could be on the chopping block, then so can yours.

If we let this go on any longer, the cost of shame would be ten times higher than any infrastructure repair cost. Aside from that school and statue of our great leader, all the buildings, no matter how important, are to be immediately destroyed, and any escaping terrorists to be eliminated. Take only a few prisoners if possible and make sure no [i]Conferri[/i] fuck blows up the statue of our great leader.
IT'S AN ORDER OFFICER!'
'S-sir...'
my heart might have stopped pumping blood for a minute, because I felt myself involuntarily taking very heavy, and very long breaths.
I wanted the breathing to stop, at least till my talk with the general was finished.
'You understand orders, don't you, officer?' My breaths only got heavier.\n\n
Stop.
FUCKING STOP!
STOP
'I said, do you or do you not understand the orders, officer?!
Because all I can hear from your side is a balloon out of air.
I want you to get your discipline back and be a man the very next moment or....'\n\n
'YES SIR!'
That shout took a lot out of my body.

At some point, though briefly, I could feel my ribcage detach from my lungs. The nerves around there stretching my skin, and all the pressure giving stress to my chest that eventually spiraled itself into my heart.
One more shout like this, and I would be there with Isamu in the medical room, wishing to wake up soon before the force learned of my weakness.

'Good. Now, straighten up, and keep your mind awake and forward the message. They have the permission to ask 30 men troop at best, and that could either be ground force or counter-terrorism, at this point I don't fucking care. Whatever gets this over, will work. I want to hear only good news 12 hours later, or you very well know that not only you, but me as well would be praying to god for our lives.'
'Thank you sir, Love to...'
Before I could give my respects, the general immediately slammed the receiver on his end. My job was clear now, and I could only wish for things to end one way or.....\n\n
No. It should only end one way, for the other way was something I could not afford.
With my ever thumping heart, I dialed the phone to my junior,

'Deploy 30 counter-terrorist squads to [i]Ufana[/i] immediately. Try Outpost 3 near [i]Ghozikla[/i] district, they seem to have the numbers and ammunition. Tell them that any property that is not the school or the great leader's statue is to be immediately blasted. If you are wishing to give any concerns on this matter, then keep them to yourself. The order comes directly from the general, and possibly the great leader himself. We have no decision on this. All we can do is follow orders. You understand.'\n\n
'Yes sir.' The junior replied on the other end.\n\n
'Good, establish communication immediately.'
Cutting the call, I immediately dialed the number to Rikki's outpost again.
A soldier picked it up.

He too tried to let out the words, 'Love to Yha...' but I cut him short saying, 'Soldier, I have no time for greetings or saluting the motherland. I want you to put Captain Rikki Takahashi immediately on the line.'\n\n
The soldier let out a very small, and very obedient,
'Yes sir,'
and shouted to one of his colleagues, 'Igarashi! Get captain Rikki on line, immediately!'
Thirty seconds later, Rikki was talking to me. His first words were, 'So, what did the general say?'\n\n

'Thirty man counter-terrorist troops are on the way. Ground soldiers will only be applicable if this is not resolved in the next 12 hours. Yes.
Yes.

[b]'Chio'[/b]
again and again in his sleep....Saying that word always brought a genuine smile on his face.\n\n
Remembering that I wished I was there with him, physical in person. Just so I could see a new version of his old smile that I last saw in training.
'Anyway,' He gathered his breath and I heard him gulp down water.

a sigh came from his end,
'we will be beginning soon.'\n\n

He-He. Oh, Yukio! Just in time. That scotch looks very fine.'
I wanted to make sure this went by the book, and also...
Something about the word 'pregnant' made me think of her.
'Yeah, kill the little bitch,'
I heard the general chuckle from the other side as he dripped some of the wine on his glass,
'both the parents are like weeds on a cultivated land. There...s no way that two weeds could ever sprout a flower.'
I heard him gulp his wine a little more,

'And by the way, I got the leave request that you forwarded through Captain Rikki. He speaks highly of how you handled the situation. I must agree with him, your quick communication has saved us a lot of time, and spared many people's heads from getting cut...ha-ha, including mine. You have earned your free time officer.'\n\n
'Thank you sir,' I spoke in a low voice, still not sure if it was proper for me to smile again.
Something still felt weird.

'Anyway, forward this last order from me, until your child's birth, that is, we will be needing you back in the field soon. To Captain Rikki, tell him to kill the bitch unless she has anything important to squeak.'\n\n
'Yes, sir.' I spoke calmly, and the general cut my call.\n\n
All that was left, was to contact Rikki himself.
'Don't say anything,'
Rikki said from the otherside, 'if the general for some reason said no, let me know, otherwise, stay silent and listen.'\n\n
I held the receiver tight, and though there were things I wished to talk with Rikki, mainly if the girl had any vital information to give, but my lips remained sealed till the end.
